description:
The protesters opposed Russian interference, government corruption, abuse of power, and human rights violations, including new anti-protest laws.[40][41]

The protests would lead to the Revolution of Dignity. On 18–20 February 2014, more than 100 protesters were killed in clashes with Berkut special riot police; most of them were shot by snipers.[42]

In the first week of the invasion, the UN reported over a million refugees had fled Ukraine; this subsequently rose to over 7,405,590 by 24 September, a reduction from over eight million due to some refugees' return.[278][279]

The invasion was internationally condemned as a war of aggression.[280][281]

There were reports of forced deportations of thousands of civilians, including children, to Russia, mainly from Russian-occupied Mariupol,[319][320] as well as sexual violence, including cases of rape, sexual assault and gang rape,[321] and deliberate killing of Ukrainian civilians by Russian forces.[322]

Reactions to the Russian invasion of Ukraine

Ukrainian public opinion

Ukrainian refugees in Kraków protest against the war, 6 March 2022
